discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.0_Study_Guide_v2-Online.pdf –> page 147 “Multiple VLANs can coexist in the same physical interface, provide they have different VLAN ID”

questions.question_text:
A FortiGate is operating in NAT mode and configured with two virtual LAN (VLAN) sub interfaces added to the physical interface.
Which statements about the VLAN sub interfaces can have the same VLAN ID, only if they have IP addresses in different subnets.

choices.B: The two VLAN sub interfaces must have different VLAN IDs.
choices.C: The two VLAN sub interfaces can have the same VLAN ID, only if they belong to different VDOMs.
choices.A: The two VLAN sub interfaces can have the same VLAN ID, only if they have IP addresses in different subnets.
choices.D: The two VLAN sub interfaces can have the same VLAN ID, only if they have IP addresses in the same subnet.

discussion.content: static routes use the Distance and Priority route attributes so A and C.

questions.question_text: Which of the following route attributes must be equal for static routes to be eligible for equal cost multipath (ECMP) routing? (Choose two.)

You have tasked to design a new IPsec deployment with the following criteria:
✑ There are two HQ sues that all satellite offices must connect to
✑ The satellite offices do not need to communicate directly with other satellite offices
✑ No dynamic routing will be used
The design should minimize the number of tunnels being configured.
//IMG//

Which topology should be used to satisfy all of the requirements?

discussion.content: B This is a hub and spoke design. Probably best not to overthink what could be occurring at the HQs between eachother, etc. as that is not mentioned.
I will go for "B" Hub and Spoke, it fits all the criteria.
Hub and Spoke is the right answer, So B is Ok.
Answer is B. The takeaway is that "The satellite offices do not need to communicate directly with other satellite offices". So no partial mesh needed
A? it should be partial mesh due not all traffic need pass to every site, but in partial mesh the routing normally is dynamic, no static.

Answer is A
Typical Setup

* There are probably at least two main sites (two “Hubs” that have direct connection to all other sites (“Spokes”)
* All other sites (the Spokes) have one direct connection to 1st main site and another direct connection to 2nd main site
* Connection from Spoke to 1st main site is probably the preferred (primary) connection
* Connection from Spoke to 2nd main site is probably the alternate (backup) connection

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding SSL VPN settings for an SSL VPN portal?

discussion.content:
There is a Trapp here... C and D have something right but the trick is the question...
Under SSL VPN settings you can see that port is 443 (same of https admin port)
BUT the question is about a SSL VPN Setting FOR A VPN PORTAL... so if you go to SSL VPN Portals and hit "Create new" you will see Tunnel Mode and Split Tunnel enabled by default... so I say the correct answer is C

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D. 
Ref. FortiGate Infrastructure 7.2 Study Guide, p.208, upper-right portion of the slide: "By default the admin GUI interface and the SSL VPN portal use the same HTTPS". port
D is correct from experience. Often causes you more likely to change the SSLVPN ports (ex. to 8443) rather than the main admin GUI from 443.
Answer D is correct, page 591 security Guide.
Split tunneling is enabled by default, but only if you enable tunnel mode manually. D is true in all cases.
D, it should be fine, same default ports, split tunnel is not enable by default in the portal ssl vpn, it needs to be enabled

choices.D: By default, the admin GUI and SSL VPN portal use the same HTTPS port.
choices.B: By default, the SSL VPN portal requires the installation of a client's certificate.
choices.C: By default, split tunneling is enabled.
choices.A: By default, FortiGate uses WINS servers to resolve names.

choices.B: Enforces device detection on all interfaces for 30 minutes.
choices.A: Reduces the amount of logs generated by denied traffic.
choices.D: Creates a session for traffic being denied.

discussion.content: A -> because by keeping the denied sessions in the session table reduces the number of session denied events in the logs, D -> because you are keeping denied sessions in the session table, Not C -> set block-session-timer {integer} Duration in seconds for blocked sessions (1 - 300 sec (5 minutes), default = 30). range[1-300]

A and D are correct, block-session-timer is in seconds not minutes
https://kb.fortinet.com/kb/documentLink.do?externalID=FD46328

C is not correct as the timer is in seconds 

Only A & D: 

Blocking the packets of a denied session can take more CPU processing resources than passing the traffic through. The configuration is to enable denied session to be added into the session table to reduce the CPU processing.
